intro: Xerololophus alpinus, commonly known as the alpine lichen, is a unique symbiotic organism composed of a fungus and a green alga or cyanobacterium. It thrives in harsh, high-altitude environments where it plays a crucial role in soil formation and nutrient cycling. The plant's structure consists of a thallus, which is a composite body formed by the mutualistic relationship between the fungal and photosynthetic partners. It is typically found on rocks, trees, or soil surfaces in cold, dry climates. Due to its specialized adaptations, Xerololophus alpinus is an important indicator species for environmental conditions in alpine regions.
